qas.question: What may have colors that do not change over several pixels?
What may have redundancy that does not change over several pixels?
What is possible because most real-world data have areas of color?
What allows many schemes to reduce lossless compression?
What do red pixel algorithms usually exploit?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Lossless data compression algorithms<b3_0/><a0_0/> usually exploit <b7_0>statistical redundancy<b7_0/> to represent data without losing any information, so that the process is reversible. <a1_0><b5_0>Lossless compression<b5_0/><a1_0/> is possible because most real-world data exhibits statistical redundancy. For example, <a2_0><b4_0>an image<b4_0/><a2_0/> may have areas of colour that do not change over several pixels; instead of coding "red pixel, red pixel, ..." the data may be encoded as "279 red pixels". This is a basic example of run-length encoding; there are many schemes to reduce file size by <b6_0>eliminating redundancy<b6_0/>.
